description: Number of partitions of n into divisors of n.
comments: Quite trivial, but a(n) = 2 iff n is prime. - _Juhani Heino_, Aug 27 2009From _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Dec 11 2009: (Start)For odd primes p: a(p^2) = p + 2; for n>1: a(A001248(n))=A052147(n);for odd primes p>3: a(3*p) = 2*p + 4; for n>2: a(A001748(n))=A100484(n)+4. (End)
references: Douglas Bowman et al., Partitions of n into parts which are divisors of n, American Mathematical Monthly 99:3 (1992), pp. 276-277.
links: T. D. Noe and Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (the first 1000 terms were computed by T. D. Noe)
Hansraj Gupta, Partitions of n into divisors of m, Indian J. Pure Appl. Math. 6:11 (1975), pp. 1276-1286.
formula: Coefficient of x^n in expansion of 1/Product_{d divides n} (1-x^d). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Sep 28 2002a(n) = f(n,n,1) with f(n,m,k) = if k<=m then f(n,m,k+1)+f(n,m-k,k)*0^(n mod k) else 0^m. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Dec 11 2009Paul ErdÅ‘s, Andrew M. Odlyzko, and the Editors of the AMM give bounds; see Bowman et al. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Dec 04 2012
mathematica: Table[d = Divisors[n]; Coefficient[Series[1/Product[1 - x^d[[i]], {i, Length[d]}], {x, 0, n}], x, n], {n, 100}] (* _T. D. Noe_, Jul 28 2011 *)
prog: (Haskell)a018818 n = p (init $ a027750_row n) n + 1 where   p _      0 = 1   p []     _ = 0   p ks'@(k:ks) m | m < k     = 0                  | otherwise = p ks' (m - k) + p ks m-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 02 2012
author: _David W. Wilson_
